body_html:
Update:
The same problem occurs with LSTM:

c_t-1 is divided by the dropout probability and grows exponentially. I guess h_t-1 should be computed using the divided c_t-1 and c_t should be updated using the unmodified c_t-1.
body_text:
Update:
The same problem occurs with LSTM:

c_t-1 is divided by the dropout probability and grows exponentially. I guess h_t-1 should be computed using the divided c_t-1 and c_t should be updated using the unmodified c_t-1.
body:
Update:
The same problem occurs with LSTM:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26974149/28434593-b7d913ca-6d44-11e7-9429-c7d6bc75ed81.png)

c_t-1 is divided by the dropout probability and grows exponentially. I guess h_t-1 should be computed using the divided c_t-1 and c_t should be updated using the unmodified c_t-1.
